clauses.clause: This directive takes effect on AprilÂ 1,Â 2021.

This directive replaces the following Treasury Board policy instrument:
Directive on Classification (AprilÂ 1,Â 2020)
This directive is issued pursuant to the same authorities indicated in sectionÂ 2 of the Policy on People Management .

In addition to the objectives indicated in sectionÂ 3 of the Policy on People Management , the objective of this directive is to support the core public administration in establishing the relative value of work in an equitable, consistent and effective manner.

In addition to the expected results indicated in sectionÂ 3 of the Policy on People Management , the expected results of this directive are as follows:
Classification authority is properly exercised; and Classification decisions are sound, and organizational design and classification activities are well managed.

Persons accredited in organizational design and classification and who have delegated classification authority are responsible for:
Evaluating jobs and approving classification decisions; Providing organizational design and classification advice; and Participating on job evaluation committees.

Persons trained in organizational design and classification are responsible for approving classification actions that do not impact or modify a classification decision, including:
Creating a position using a standardized job description; Deleting a position; and Changing the reporting relationship or title of a position.
The roles of other government organizations in relation to this directive are described in sectionÂ 5 of the Policy on People Management .
This directive applies to the organizations listed in sectionÂ 6 of the Policy on People Management .
This directive does not apply to positions classified in the Executive (EX) Group.
This directive does not apply to persons appointed by the Governor in Council, to members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, or to members of the Canadian Armed Forces.
